titleInfo.title: McKinley High School Oral History Project: Baton Rouge Bus Boycott
titleInfo.subTitle: James John Batiste Sr. oral history interview, 1998

name.description: James Batiste was born in New Roads, La., to Lawrence Batiste Sr. and Albertha Sims Batiste. He has three brothers: Lawrence Jr., Sam, and Wilson. Batiste lived in Rougon, La., for a time but was raised primarily in Scotlandville, La., where he attended Scotlandville High School. He moved to Port Allen, La., when he was seventeen. Batiste is married to Mary Bell of Lakeland, La. He has eight children, one stepchild, and sixteen grandchildren. At the time of this interview, Batiste was on the janitorial staff at McKinley High School in Baton Rouge where he had worked since 1980.

mods.abstract: Batiste discusses civil rights activism in Baton Rouge during the late 1950s and 1960s. He describes in detail the bus system in Scotlandville and the differences in the Baton Rouge city bus system which had segregated seating. He describes instances of racism and prejudice that he faced and witnessed as a teenager and young man. He discusses voting drives, pickets and boycotts he took part in, and resulting arrests.
